Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no scientific consensus on the efficacy of homemade masks in stopping the spread of COVID-19.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the chart accurately shows the effectiveness of wearing face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic, but there is no confirmation of the accuracy of these statistics.
Exist alternative explanation: There are alternative explanations for the effectiveness of face masks, as different types of masks provide different levels of protection against the spread of disease. The chart does not specify the type of mask being used.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no enough data to quantify the risk reduction from the use of masks, according to the CDC.
Understate: The claim may understate the effectiveness of face masks by not considering the potential benefits of wearing them in public settings to slow the spread of the virus, as recommended by the CDC.
